description: Borrowed from Latin idea (“a (Platonic) idea; archetype”), from Ancient Greek ἰδέα (idéa, “notion, pattern”), from εἴδω (eídō, “I see”), ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *weyd- (“to know; see”). Cognate with French idée. Doublet of idée. Related to idol, idolum, and eidolon.

entries.meaning: (philosophy) An abstract archetype of a given thing, compared to which real-life examples are seen as imperfect approximations; pure essence, as opposed to actual examples. [from 14th c.]
(obsolete) The conception of someone or something as representing a perfect example; an ideal. [16th–19th c.]
(obsolete) The form or shape of something; a quintessential aspect or characteristic. [16th–18th c.]
An image of an object that is formed in the mind or recalled by the memory. [from 16th c.]
examples: The mere idea of you is enough to excite me.

entries.meaning: More generally, any result of mental activity; a thought, a notion; a way of thinking. [from 17th c.]
A conception in the mind of something to be done; a plan for doing something, an intention. [from 17th c.]
examples: I have an idea of how we might escape.

entries.meaning: A purposeful aim or goal; intent
A vague or fanciful notion; a feeling or hunch; an impression. [from 17th c.]
examples: He had the wild idea that if he leant forward a little, he might be able to touch the mountain-top.

entries.meaning: (music) A musical theme or melodic subject. [from 18th c.]
